response.answer_text: Things that helped me out: Sheduling. But take care of yourself as well: eat, drink, sleep, go out. And try to not miss any day of writing.  Resource: How to Plan Thesis Writing in the Kittenish Way? Pomodoro Technique. Helps to concentrate on writing. There are six steps in the technique: Decide on the task to be done.Set the pomodoro timer (traditionally to 25 minutes).Work on the task until the timer rings. If a distraction pops into your head, write it down, but immediately get back on task.After the timer rings, put a checkmark on a piece of paper.If you have fewer than four checkmarks, take a short break (3–5 minutes), then go to step 2.After four pomodoros, take a longer break (15–30 minutes), reset your checkmark count to zero, then go to step 1.Google Docs and its alternatives will help you to always have access to your work.

Your dissertation is your union card. It is your entry into the academy. But writing a dissertation can seem overwhelming. It’s scary to imagine writing a work 200 or more pages and submitting it to distinguished scholars whose opinion of your intelligence and talent will depend on what you have completed. But remember: The single biggest obstacle to completion is psychological. To be sure, a dissertation involves far more research than you have ever done before. But by the time you begin your dissertation, you’ve already written countless essays, lab reports, and conference presentations.  A dissertation is, in the end, simply a compilation of seminar papers—revised to provide conceptual unity. Completing a dissertation, then, is mainly a matter of perseverance. When we say we can't focus we can refer to different things. For instance, the problem may lie in the fear of failure, lack of sleep, lack of proper nutrition, inability to find that "golden" seat which would just inspire you to get to work. I am just going to throw some ideas in there and hope you find them helpful. Why are you writing a dissertation? What are your main motivators? Are you excited about doing the research? If not, what could be changed in order to make this inspired work, not a chore.Once you know your answers to #1, what will happen if you don't get it done? Are there any consequences you will have to face? Is there a deadline?Do you have a "sweet" writing spot or a "golden" seat, which kicks your brain into the right gear once you take it? If not, train yourself to work in this one location that you like. Being consistent will teach you to get straight to work once you are there.Make sure you consume the food that gives you mental energy, not sluggishness. Get enough sleep. Unplug daily at least for one hour. Get time outside. Read books related and not related to your subject.Have fun!
